article: I was working on my usual Sunday afternoon shift at the bakery. The flow of _ rushed to finish weekend shopping in order to return home _ to prepare supper or watch the football game. I _ on my job of stamping hundreds of bags for the coming holiday weekend _ I heard a weak voice, "Excuse me, miss." I _ up to see an elderly man standing before me. He _ asked if he could have a tart . I went to fetch the tart and placed it in a box. "Three dollars, please." I told him. The man looked _ and began shaking his head. This is one of the most awkward _ , because you want to give the dessert away, but cannot. He apologized, saying he would not _ more than expected on a tart.  _ I felt upset, I waited on the customer behind him, a woman who asked for various breads and desserts _ , she asked if I would _ adding a tart to her bill and placing it in a _ box. My curiosity grew as I handed it to her. She paid, _ me and walked away. I _ to stamping bags, but I couldn't concentrate. I could not stop thinking about the little old man who could not, or _ not, spend three dollars on a dessert. Just then, I saw the woman giving the man _ much-desired tart. His face _ , brilliant and appreciative. lit up her kindness, he reached into his pocket and gave her the only thing he had: a piece of candy.
